title: Reversing Type 2 diabetes starts with ignoring the guidelines | Sarah Hallberg | TEDxPurdueU
description:
Can a person be "cured" of Type 2 Diabetes? Dr. Sarah Hallberg provides compelling evidence that it can, and the solution is simpler than you might think.

Dr. Sarah Hallberg is the Medical Director of the Medically Supervised Weight Loss Program at IU Health Arnett, a program she created. She is board certified in both obesity medicine and internal medicine and has a Master’s Degree in Exercise Physiology. She has recently created what is only the second non-surgical weight loss rotation in the country for medical students. Her program has consistently exceeded national benchmarks for weight loss, and has been highly successful in reversing diabetes and other metabolic diseases. Dr. Hallberg is also the co-author of www.fitteru.us, a blog about health and wellness.

B.S., Kinesiology & Exercise Science, Illinois State University, 1994

M.S., Kinesiology & Exercise Science, Illinois State University, 1996

M.D., Des Moines University, 2002

This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at http://ted.com/tedx

title: 5 tips to improve your critical thinking - Samantha Agoos
description:
View full lesson: http://ed.ted.com/lessons/5-tips-to-improve-your-critical-thinking-samantha-agoos

Every day, a sea of decisions stretches before us, and it’s impossible to make a perfect choice every time. But there are many ways to improve our chances — and one particularly effective technique is critical thinking. Samantha Agoos describes a 5-step process that may help you with any number of problems. 

Lesson by Samantha Agoos, animation by Nick Hilditch.

This is definitely a great video that explores critical thinking skills, though I also think that when people are learning about skepticism and critical thinking skills that it's important not to conflate them with cynicism, since there are going to be moments in life where skepticism and logic wouldn't always be involved (such as falling in love, acknowledging/facing fears, expressing empathy and compassion, and so on). 
Personally, I think that forgiveness and understanding on being human should be added to lessons on critical thinking and cognitive biases so that there's balance to developing their cognitive skills.

It's like how you write an experiment in science. Aim(formulate the question), Apparatus, theory, (gather information), Procedure(apply information), Observations(consider the implications), precautions/sources of error(explore other points of view).

Logic is that has a formula, namely as a law of cause and implication.

A ∨ B ∨ C ∨ ....etc ⇒ Z  ----------> Logic formula

                                      
A=(a1 ∧ a2 ∧ a3 ∧ a4 ∧....etc)       -----> cause
B=(b1 ∧ b2 ∧ b3 ∧ b4 ∧ b5 ∧...etc)   -----> cause
C=(c1 ∧ c2 ∧ c3 ∧ c4 ∧...etc)        -----> cause
D=(d1 ∧ d2 ∧ d3 ∧ d4 ∧ d5 ∧...etc)   -----> cause
                                       
Z=(z1 ∧ z2 ∧z3 ∧ z4 ∧....etc)  -----> implication

∨  is an abstract symbol for or
∧  is an abstract symbol for and
⇒ is an abstract symbol for implication
¬  is an abstract symbol for not  

To think logically is to make an logic equation by
replacing the abstract symbol at in logical formulas
either in cause or implication or both at once with
whatever we think then we compare it to reality then
everything will look more clearly.

The logic equation is always certain (consistent)
and precision because the logic equation is law
of nature so that if a logical equation arises
compared to natural law it is not consistent then
it is suspected that the equation is has a problem
referred to as paradox.

With a simple logic formula it turns out that it can
explain most of the logic problems like analogy,
deductive, inductive, paradox and proof.

The analogy is if A ≠ B we enter into a logical formula
will form the following logic equation:

if         "A ⇒ Z"         ✓(true)
then   "A ∨ B ⇒ Z"  ?(maybe true) --->analogy.

Deductive and inductive is when CC = (cc1, cc2, cc3,
cc4, cc5, .... etc.) where CC is a group and cc1,
cc2, cc3, ... etc. are members of CC group, if we
enter into the logic formula it will form the following
logic equation:

if          "CC ⇒ Z"                                             ✓(true)              
then    "CC ∨ cc1 ∨ cc2 ∨ cc3 ∨ ...etc ⇒Z" ✓(certainly
true) ----> deductive.

if           "cc1 ⇒ Z"            ✓(true) 
then      "cc1 ∨ CC ⇒ Z"  ?(maybe true) ---> inductive.

The paradox is when the two same logical equations 
but with conflicting consequences like following:

if there                !  "A ⇒ Z"  !
                             !                  ! ----> paradox 
but also there    ! "A ⇒ ¬Z" !

title: David Icke: Conspiracy of the Lizard Illuminati (Part 1/2)
description:
Conspiracy theorist David Icke takes us to a local satanic execution site and discusses the plot of the secret lizard illuminati.

We traveled to the Isle of Wight to meet the most iconic conspiracy theorist on Earth, David Icke. A former professional goalkeeper and television presenter, David Icke found international fame back in the 90s when he began uncovering a secret lizard illuminati plot. Icke discovered that a race of shape-shifting lizards has been masquerading as presidents and monarchs for centuries while planning to crush the planet.

In Part 2, Icke takes VICE host Kevin Morpurgo to the site of a local Satanic execution and explains what the global cabal of pedophile aliens has to do with Stanley Kubrick and Bill Clinton. 

Watch part 2/2 here: http://bit.ly/David-Icke-2

title: I grew up in the Westboro Baptist Church. Here's why I left | Megan Phelps-Roper
description:
What's it like to grow up within a group of people who exult in demonizing ... everyone else? Megan Phelps-Roper shares details of life inside America's most controversial church and describes how conversations on Twitter were key to her decision to leave it. In this extraordinary talk, she shares her personal experience of extreme polarization, along with some sharp ways we can learn to successfully engage across ideological lines.

TEDTalks is a daily video podcast of the best talks and performances from the TED Conference, where the world's leading thinkers and doers give the talk of their lives in 18 minutes (or less). Look for talks on Technology, Entertainment and Design -- plus science, business, global issues, the arts and much more.

title: The Rogue Tesla Mechanic Resurrecting Salvaged Cars
description:
Rich is a car enthusiast whose passion is to find wrecked Teslas, bring them back to life, and then share his repair adventures on his YouTube channel Rich Rebuilds.

When he found out that Tesla would not service or support his salvaged cars, he took it upon himself to scour the internet and harvest working parts from several busted Teslas. He Frankensteined them together until his creations were fully operational, at a fraction of what it would cost to buy a new or certified pre-owned Tesla. 

Motherboard travels to Massachusetts to meet with the rogue mechanic leading a grassroots movement of DIY fixers who are taking back the right to repair the things they own.

Check out Rich's YouTube channel: https://bit.ly/2BAD9Uc

Great piece.  Sadly, the fact is that conventional car manufacturers have been moving in the direction of "only we can repair it" for years. Doing things like locking the ECU's to various other components, so, for example, you cannot swap out your defective dash computer for a salvaged one (Volvo) to not making it possible to get a new key for your car from anyone but them (BMW).  It's a genuine scandal that our elected lawmakers aren't getting in line on this issue and ensuring that the right to repair is guaranteed when it comes to software.  It should be the trade off for the copyright protections that software enjoys that source code must be made public... the same way patent designs become public but are protected.  The trouble holding things back is not in autos, but in the billion dollar consumer electronics industry. Who is going to keep upgrading their iPhone for $600+ every 2 years, when they can flash software updates from third parties that keep it running... or who are able to take control over the apps that appear on their TV's and video players... or, better yet, who can change a few lines of code and ensure that great online games stay online forever with community based servers when the original developer tries to shut them down to get you to buy the newer (often crappier) game, or to make all that loot you've accumulated and/or bought with hard cash essentially worthless overnight.

maybe the universe doesnt exist.

like when you dream, there are crazy things happening, then you wake up and realise it was all nonsense.

so you need to first ask "does the universe exist?"

eg with quantum mechanics things only exist if you observe them
which means existence is something strange.

but before the above question, you need to ask "what is existence?"

existence means something just is, 

but nothing just is, because for something to be, it needs to be relative to something else,
but to which something else?

(everything also is continually changing, so something can only just be for one instant in time,
after that it is something different: you cannot step into the same river twice).

essentially existence is relative, eg I have a calculator on my desk and it exists relative to me,
but you cannot see it, and I could be lying, so essentially for you it doesnt exist.

this isnt just hypothetical, because say you have a book you read 10 years ago (or a film you watched)
which you found really interesting. If you read the book again now, you will find its not so interesting,
and you will wonder why you thought it was good. Its because when you read a book, it is relative
to what you know and are just now. eg a book may be explaining clever ways to make money on the stock
exchange. But then you try the ideas out over some months and lose all your money. So in 10 years time
when you start reading the book again, you throw it away because you know its wrong, and 
also know why its wrong.


if you really scrutinise things like the original question, you will get a migraine, because you are trying to use logic,
but all logic rests upon axioms, things you take to be true without question,

ie logic is always relative, there is no such thing as absolute logic. logic is always only a way of furtherance,
to further a structure, logic is not about initialising. The initialisation of a logical system begins by looking at
pre-existing examples. 

so its all futile, you are trying to establish "everything" using "logic", but "logic" can only establish things relatively,
so it cant be done. the problem is the word "why" in the question "why does the universe exist?". "why" is to explain one thing in terms of others. But then how to explain those others? To explain them in terms of even more others. Eventually you have to stop.
So its like to utilise a dictionary, you need to already know a lot of words. Provided you know some critical mass of words, you can then learn more from a dictionary. Where do the initial words come from? from context, ie from examples of things and someone using the word for the things. 

if a question leads to going round and round in circles, like the above video, then you should abandon the question,
find questions where you progress. As a general rule you should start with very basic questions,
eg a much more basic question is "what is the easiest way to make money?",

that itself can be preceded by an even more basic question:

"is there any easy way to make money?"

give an example.

I personally think the only easy ways to make money depend on you already having money,
if you dont have any money then it is very difficult to make money, the poverty trap.

Now you see here, that by asking a basic question I have started to make some progress. That you need money to make money,
so we can look at another question, how do you make money using money? 

If you start with very basic questions, you can gradually ask more difficult questions, when they are too difficult, then back off
and try something else.

But if you go to "meaning of everything" questions, you will never progress, all you end up doing is perhaps understanding the question better.

you shouldnt waste time on such questions, toy around with them for a bit, but eventually get the point that the question is a bad question.

Since many people misunderstand, or copy the misunderstanding about buddhism, when informing themselves about it: The statement "nothing = the world, the world = nothing" does not describe the essence or worldview of buddhist thought. 
There is a term in buddhism, which can be translated into something like "emptiness" or "nothingness", but this word refers more to the fact, that every obeject (human, a car, an animal, a plant, an atom, anything) is empty of a self. Everything is ever changing, not in any moment the same as before. If you think this through all the way - or better do a few vipassana retreats - you will understand/know that "emptiness" (or "nothingsness", as Holt refers to here) = everything is everything else, and thus empty of a self. If you really want to understand it, sunyata is the original Pali word.

For those who want to learn more, I highly recommend the book by Michael Nielsen introducing neural networks and deep learning: https://goo.gl/Zmczdy

There are two neat things about this book.  First, it's available for free, so consider joining me in making a donation Nielsen's way if you get something out of it. Written some notes from the video to read quickly. Hope it helps somebody. 

l Neural Networks can recognize hand written digits, letters, words ( in general, tokens )
 l What are Neurons?
  ○ Something that holds a number [ 0, 1]
  ○ The higher the number, the higher the "activation" rate
 l Consider a 28*28 table in which each unit is represented by a value between 0 to 1 ( activation number )
  ○ Let us divide each row into a "layer", such that, if we were to divide all the layers, the last layer would contain 10 "cells" ( units ).
  ○ Values are passed from the previous cells to the last layer ( 10 unit layer ), again, between 0 and 1. The higher or closer the value is to 1, the more probability exists that the image scanned represents that unit cell.
    So, a unit cell that contains the highest value is indication that the index of the unit cell is the value of the image scanned.
  ○ 16 cells in the second and third last cells are arbitrary.
  ○ Each cell is linked ( causes activation ) to some ( not all ) other cells in the next layer which further cause more activation.
  ○ Each 'cell' corresponds to some sort of identification about how much a certain region 'lights up', and then sends a value to another node which reacts based on the received value. 
  ○ To find whether a certain cell with light us, like each cell be represented by 'a Cell_Number ', and let each cell be 'assigned' a certain weight 'w'. The sum of all the products of each cells 'a' and 'w' will be:  
   w1*a1 + w2*a2 + w3*a3 + w4*a4 + …  + wn*an 
  ○ Let these weighted sums represent some 'grid cell'. Each cell is either 'on' or 'off' with respect to being positive or negative. In this case, 'green' represents on, and 'red' represents off.
  ○ Let us concern ourselves to a certain region where the cells are mostly on. Ergo, we would be basically summing up the weightages of those grid cells.
  ○ Then, if you suppose a region where there are brighter grid cells in some part which are surrounded by dark grid cells, then that area is the main edge we're looking for.
  ○ Of course the sum of weightages gives us very different value. In order to 'squish' that number line into 0 and 1 , we use the function:
   Sigma(x) = 1/(1 + e^-x)
  Which is a sigmoid function or a Logistic Curve. Our equation now becomes:
   Sigmoid(w1*a1 + w2*a2 + w3*a3 + w4*a4 + …  + wn*an)
  ○ But what if you don't always want to light up when it's a positive value, and rather want it to light up when the weighted sum of that grid cell full fills some condition, such as > 10. This is called 'Bias For Inactivity'. Using this example, our equation becomes,
   Sigmoid(w1*a1 + w2*a2 + w3*a3 + w4*a4 + …  + wn*an  - 10)
   Here, 10 is the "bias".
  ○ The possibilities of the different knobs and dials open us to the term of "Learning", which just means to find the correct relation of values which perform the expected behavior. 
  ○ The complete expression above can be adjusted in the formula:
   a(1) = Sigma(W*a(0) + b )
   ( (1) and (0) are superscript here )

   Where W = k*n matrix whose elements are weights corresponding to a cell.
   a(0) = n*1 matrix whose elements are the 'a' of each cell.
   b= n*1 matrix whose elements are the biases of each cell 
  ○ NOTE: Sigmoid function is not used very often now, instead it is replaced by ReLU ( Rectified Linear Unity ), which is defined as:
ReLU(a) = max(0, a), a linear function where f(a) = a for a>= 0, which for a < 0, f(a) = 0.

title: Why you will fail to have a great career | Larry Smith | TEDxUW
description:
Never miss a talk! SUBSCRIBE to the TEDx channel: http://bit.ly/1FAg8hB

Throughout his three-decade career here at the University of Waterloo, Larry Smith has inspired legions of students to take up the mantle of economics with his passionate and homespun tales of economic wizardry. A renowned story-teller, teacher and youth leadership champion, Larry has also coached and mentored countless numbers of students on start-up business management and career development strategies.

Having taught introductory microeconomics, macroeconomics and entrepreneurship classes, he recently celebrated assigning his 29,000th grade earlier this year.

Recipient of the Distinguished Teacher Award, Larry has also coached several of his former students to help them position and develop their businesses, the most famous of which is Research in Motion (RIM), maker of the revolutionary BlackBerry wireless mobile smartphone. Larry also sits on the advisory panels of start-ups to provide his guidance on financing and negotiation with investors and venture capitalists.

http://www.tedxuw.com/speakers/larry-smith/

---

In the spirit of ideas worth spreading, TEDx is a program of local, self-organized events that bring people together to share a TED-like experience. At a TEDx event, TEDTalks video and live speakers combine to spark deep discussion and connection in a small group. These local, self-organized events are branded TEDx, where x = independently organized TED event. The TED Conference provides general guidance for the TEDx program, but individual TEDx events are self-organized.* (*Subject to certain rules and regulations)

I will add Japanese version translation here, I hope it will be helpful somehow.
日本語訳(一言一句同じにしてるわけではないです、1ミリくらい情報加えて分かりやすく？もしてます)を載せておきます、参考程度になれば幸いです。

--

今回我々が提供するビジネスモデルは、基本的に9つのセクションから成り立ちます。

「顧客 / Customer Segments」、
「バリュープロポジション / Value Propositions」(顧客の為に何の問題を解決したいのか、何を提供したいのか)、
「トンネル / Channel」(我々が提供する商品 (物、システム、等)を顧客に届ける方法)、
「顧客との関係性 / Customer Relationships」(我々が顧客とどのように接しビジネスを進めていきたいか)、
「収入源 / Revenue Streams」、
「主な資源 / Key Resources」(価値を創り出すために必要となる資源: 物や情報等)
「主な活動 / Key Activities」、
「キーパートナー / Key Partnerships」(投資者や共同開発を行う会社等)、
そして「支出 / Cost Structure」です。

まあこうやってカテゴリーを言っていくだけでは分かりづらいので、これらを一つの地図のように配置していきましょう。

これがビジネスモデルキャンバス呼ばれるもので、新たなるビジネスのデザインや創造に非常に役立ちます。
ではサラッとこの9つのカテゴリーがどのように関係しているのか見ていきましょう。

--

まずは「顧客」から始めましょう。これはモデル発案者のグループがどのような人々を対象にビジネスをしたいかを考えるセクションです。

「バリュープロポジション」はこのモデルの心臓部のようなもので、これが他のセクションの動向を左右します。
(あまりにも分かりづらかったので表現を変えました、ビデオでは、「各セクションには具体的なバリュープロポジションが存在し、これが我々が提供する商品やサービスを一括りにするバンドのような役割をしています」と、このようなことを言っています。)

「トンネル」は、どのような点で顧客と繋がっていたいか(SNS等)、コミュニケーションを取っていきたいのか、そして価値をどのように提供していくのかについてのセクションです。

「顧客との関係性」、このセクションでは、実際にどのような関係性を顧客と築いていきたいのかです。

「収入」のセクションでは、どのようにお金を集めていくかについて考察します。

次に、どのように我々の価値を創造し、提供し、収入を得ていくかというインフラのようなものを説明していかなくてはなりません
「主な資源」では、何がこのビジネスモデルを完成させるにおいて欠けてはならないのかを表します。

「主な活動」では、我々はこのビジネスモデルを実現するために何が出来なくてはならないのか、やらなくてはならないのかを考えていきます。

「キーパートナー」では、誰が、どのような機関が我々のビジネスモデルの活性化に必要なのかを洗い出していきます。ビジネスを進めていく中で「あぁこれが出来ない、あれが足りない」なんてやりたくないですよね(笑)

そして、全ての情報が整ったら、最後はこのビジネスモデルがどのくらいの「支出」を必要とするのかを考察します。

--

さて、これら全ての情報がそろったら、このキャンバスを使って一つのイメージのように可視化していきます。
これは起業家のスタートアップにも、上級管理者にとっても使いやすいモデルとなっております。

When perception occurs, there is distortion of absolute infinite reality, and that is what creates what is uniquely a human reality, which appears fractal in nature and "governed" by natural laws. Mathematic and physics for us is like language; it allows us to conceptualize the notion of individual "bodies" by drawing boundaries around certain to-scale relative packets of relative information, basically pulling the abstract out of thin air and supposing it to be parceled out just as we imagine it. This is false, because there are no bodies in what is absolute reality. In truth, everything that is measured is measured on a number line with infinity on one side and zero on the other. Neither one can truly exist because neither infinity nor zero may ever truly be realized, although there is an obvious allusion to both in our perception of things. In the reality that is beyond finiteness, which can by its very definition not be "real" or "realized" by an approximating perceiving body, there is only infinitely increasing and decreasing scales of relative information and intersections of the interactions of that information which are pertinent to our existences as the relative creatures we are. Anything beyond our scale of "usefulness" by function of its lack of relativity in scale ceases to be. That is why understanding the incredibly small and understanding the incredibly large is about as limited as actually attaining "absolute zero" or calculating pi to its final decimal value. The feats are impossible to achieve, not because we do not understand something about theoretical physics or the universe, but because we refuse to acknowledge that there are breaks in the laws of what we are capable of, as finite relative approximating creatures. 

The answer to Einsteins issue about whether the moon was there or not when he turned his back, and particle-wave duality is not a question of physics; it's a question of whether or not we can accept that only does the infinite body become realized, in other words, conceptualized as or made finite, when it is relatively and therefor finitely approximated in its value by the perceiving body and thus pulled out of nowhere, into a world of abstraction. The duality of particles depends on whether or not we approximate them, because in truth they are infinite. Infinite bodies cannot exist however, by definition, because a boundary must be drawn, and so it becomes rather, a question of perception and skew and nothing else.

- Forrest Reed

The explanation for me is that all particles are fundamentally localized waves or vibrations. Only waves exist. What we think of as particles are interactions between these waves, including Einstein's experiment. In Einstein's experiment the photon wave has, depending on various details, some probability of interacting with the electron wave, and when it happens, the electron wave changes its path and electron gets ejected. In the double slit experiment the single photon wave passes through both slits, the passage affecting the details of its probability of interacting with other waves. The single photon wave hits the screen at a single or rather confined location because when it interacts with the electron waves in the screen, it has to do so at the location of a single electron wave (I have to reconfirm my memory that a  single photon can only interact with a single particle at a time), the wave does not collapse into a particle, but interacts with a single other wave and we observe this interaction AT THE LOCATION of the electron (i.e. it is localization but not really a wave collapse or change from wave to particle). The part I am still working my understand through is how passing through a slit affects the probability distribution for interacting with electrons.

I don't know if the following has an impact on the point your making, since the double slit experiment doesn't involve the splitting of photon bundles (at least not knowingly). However, each bundle (or photon packet) can be broken into parts (two photon packets). There have been photon teleportation experiments repeated many times in recent years, which involve splitting single photon packet into two photon packets. The two photon packets, resulting from a single split photon, have a linked quantum state and information can be sent from one photon to its quantum linked photon regardless of distance. So they've experimentally proven Einstein's "spooky action at a distance." In one of the latest experiments (sometime last year I believe), Chinese scientists successfully performed this photon/quantum teleportation with the photon pair as far apart as a satellite in earth's orbit and the earth's surface.

title: Every kid needs a champion | Rita Pierson
description:
Rita Pierson, a teacher for 40 years, once heard a colleague say, "They don't pay me to like the kids." Her response: "Kids don't learn from people they don't like.'" A rousing call to educators to believe in their students and actually connect with them on a real, human, personal level.

TEDTalks is a daily video podcast of the best talks and performances from the TED Conference, where the world's leading thinkers and doers give the talk of their lives in 18 minutes (or less). Look for talks on Technology, Entertainment and Design -- plus science, business, global issues, the arts and much more.
Find closed captions and translated subtitles in many languages at http://www.ted.com/translate

Still haven’t subscribed to WIRED on YouTube? ►► http://wrd.cm/15fP7B7 


ABOUT WIRED
WIRED is where tomorrow is realized. Through thought-provoking stories and videos, WIRED explores the future of business, innovation, and culture.

Quantum Computing Expert Explains One Concept in 5 Levels of Difficulty | WIRED

comments.topLevelComment: Steve is so cute and the grad student was annoying and seemingly very cocky tbh

"[Quantum communication channels are] provably secure based on the laws on physics": This is true if "laws of physics" means "our current ideas on how best to formulate quantum mechanics". But security is always (I think) also about imagining future potential threats. And while quantum mechanics is probably the best tested (not just physics) theory in the world, there is no way to scientifically prove that the future won't bring about new insights that might make quantum communication channels insecure. Since that's generally true about anything I guess it's not a bit deal, but the idea of "provable security" I think isn't very helpful.

title: The paradox of choice | Barry Schwartz
description:
http://www.ted.com Psychologist Barry Schwartz takes aim at a central tenet of western societies: freedom of choice. In Schwartz's estimation, choice has made us not freer but more paralyzed, not happier but more dissatisfied.

TEDTalks is a daily video podcast of the best talks and performances from the TED Conference, where the world's leading thinkers and doers are invited to give the talk of their lives in 18 minutes -- including speakers such as Jill Bolte Taylor, Sir Ken Robinson, Hans Rosling, Al Gore and Arthur Benjamin. TED stands for Technology, Entertainment, and Design, and TEDTalks cover these topics as well as science, business, politics and the arts. Watch the Top 10 TEDTalks on TED.com, at
http://www.ted.com/index.php/talks/top10

The "Official Dogma"
a Maximize welfare
b This means maximize freedom
c <which in turn> means maximize choice
d More choice means more freedom
e More freedom means more welfare


1 The word choice is synonymous with the word freedom. There is no place where you cannot substitute one for the other, excepting only that choice tends to be used as an individual instance of freedom.

2 This renders point d redundant and useless.

3 Either b or c is superfluous.

4 The argument condensed is "In order to maximize welfare, you must maximize choice/freedom." which is summed up as a tautological oroborus in e.

5 This list cannot be a representation of official dogma as it is not even a possible contention.

Mr. Schwartz has some good points but he's tilting at windmills here. Many of his other arguments, especially in the beginning were also over-stated. There aren't really that many stereo choices because not all things work together, among other problems. If you're correct you don't need to exaggerate.


Bonus: 

positive freedom (to be actively progressive) - to be able to accomplish things
:positive choice - to be able to accomplish things

negative freedom (from restraint) - to be allowed to accomplish things
:negative choice - not your choice

These things that he's talking about are the musings of a perpetual adolescent.  One doesn't have to be disappointed because he chose the best fitting jeans in the store.  You can take several salad dressings and you can have the one that fits your mood or fits best with the different components that you can make various types of salad from.  He speaks as if his take on this "choice" matter is universal, but it's not.  Furthermore, his arguments, based on logical fallacies, have a definite purpose, as most fallacious arguments do.  He is pushing an argument in favor of global income redistribution, to "help" us with our "too many choices" and provide those choices to the rest of the planet.  However, it doesn't require us to give up our choices for the rest of the world to have more choices.  What, we should ship half of our salad dressing choices to the third world?

Also, historically, the redistribution of wealth doesn't affect the most affluent people on the planet, the so-called 1%.  Instead, it involves middle-class people giving up what they have to help those in less-developed areas of the world.  The real wealth redistribution that would make sense globally would be to take the wealth of the elites, those in the wealthiest 10% of the population who own over 90% of the world's wealth and resources, and redistribute that to the rest of us.  But that is never on the table.

This dovetails nicely with things I've learned from the minimalism movement. Ex: If you get a fancy new pair of jeans, you'll be sad they're not perfect. Excellent and subscribed. But. While the info you provided was great and accurate, you misled us a little. Yes, a 4k TV may have more pixels than our eyes do... but we don't watch the whole screen at any one time. We watch whatever on the screen catches our attention, and that can be anywhere on the screen and a small subset of the screen. Because of that, a screen's maximum resolution, to where there is no more benefit to higher resolution, is that point at which increasing pixels in a localized spot does not give any benefit. This gets into seating distance, of course. But, at normal distance, a 4k tv looks better, which is why they are selling. Thanks for the great info.

Any body who has worked in traditional corporate environments can understand why these companies fail when a technological inflection takes place. Steve itself mentioned this in an interview.. The early precursor of these companies are innovative and filled with people passionately believing in the innovation they are bringing, They work hard and take risks to make a leap of faith. Lo and behold they introduce something brilliant and grows tremendously. The golden ideas they build their success on becomes the mainstream and the companies slowly push the innovation driven risk takers out of the board room into back offices and research jobs. The marketing and the sales types get promoted as they are considered to be the ones bringing in the customers and the money. The marketing guys at best understands what goes inside of their products in a trivial fashion or they understand only sales numbers and customer feedback. They simply cant connect the dots well.
They don't understand that the DNA of a great product is forward thinking before the market and having vision and commitment to make that into a reality. A path breaking product cannot be build just on customer feedback alone because most customers know only the current possibility. The marketing leaders in the board room also don't get it. The Xerox case or the Kodak case exactly demonstrates it. 
The R&D types who are never in the board rooms are rarely is listened to. Steve's brilliance is understanding how a customer would understand the value of a technology. One of his critical abilities was to translate and package technology in the way a consumer will want to experience it. In short Product vision. To be a product leader you should be both a technocrat as well as a first class business executive.
Even Steve didn't really succeed with the Mac. It was not a run away financial success as Steve expected.  Apple made more money from Lisa than the Mac. He was pushed out of the company by Scully over differences on strategy. He then went on to make Next computer, a high end computer for education sector. Steve went back to perfecting technology, understand emerging technologies and learning the ropes of market innovation in Next. One thing he always did was to surrounding him with the best engineering and design people. He was willing to pay premium for that.
Most people don't how advanced Next OS was in 1992-93. It had all features like seamless mail integration and clickable context based content processing with rich media, seamless content type detection and data sharing between applications. etc. The OS was entirely written using OOP(Object oriented programming) paradigm(Except for the core kernel I believe).
Apple was slowly losing market share through the early 90's since Scully based it on the DTP  use-cases that Steve had identified for it and then they stopped innovating. Some of the disgruntled team in Apple left and created BeOS and the  BeBox. I had worked with this OS too. Very advanced for its time. Steve was reinventing himself and his strategic vision.  Luckily for him, Apple was in dire straits by 95-96. They had terrible failure in bringing a true Mult-tasking operating system with advancements in memory management. Meanwhile Next and BeOS were by the time doing true pre-emptive multitasking which optimizes the way application uses memory and cpu resources. Meaning faster and responsive system on relatively cheaper hardware that allowed users to quickly switch between Back ground and foreground tasks.
Apple bought NExt for the technology and Steve insisted on his old position in the company. He ruthlessly threw people who opposed him out of the firm. He was battle hardened and experienced by now. Steve created his own team of brilliant engineers. The first product that came out was the iMAC, those beautiful well engineered machines with translucent cases with monitors and the computer in one enclosure. That was Steves move to get his customers excited in Apple again, with a computer of great aesthetic and user experience value. Apple was back in the innovation business. The engineering core of the NExt OS became the MacOS X. The rest is history.

title: How to escape education's death valley | Sir Ken Robinson
description:
Sir Ken Robinson outlines 3 principles crucial for the human mind to flourish -- and how current education culture works against them. In a funny, stirring talk he tells us how to get out of the educational "death valley" we now face, and how to nurture our youngest generations with a climate of possibility.

TEDTalks is a daily video podcast of the best talks and performances from the TED Conference, where the world's leading thinkers and doers give the talk of their lives in 18 minutes (or less). Look for talks on Technology, Entertainment and Design -- plus science, business, global issues, the arts and much more.
Find closed captions and translated subtitles in many languages at http://www.ted.com/translate

Follow TED news on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/tednews
Like TED on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/TED

Subscribe to our channel: http://www.youtube.com/user/TEDtalksDirector

Education was something that a few really interested individuals did in the past. Not because they had to, but because they were hungry for knowledge and wanted to learn. Even today you walk into any university or industry and you will find that there are but a handful of people who actually love what they do or know what they are doing. Without them these institutions or companies will fade away or collapse in time.  However, today more than ever in human history, children are sent to school. Many of them from families with little or no education. These parents have never experienced higher levels of thinking. In fact this is a territory in their view where pain resides.  Intelligence is associated with dishonesty and corruption. So they plant this seed into their children’s minds at an early age. It is also likely that learning is not high on their priority list. So, they enter the education system and the world expects miracles. And miracles do happen but not of the same magnitude or rate  that people expect. Now I am not saying that the education system is perfect by any means. But neither are our expectations. For the masses, enslaved by ignorance, out dated beliefs and ideas  we need to adjust our expectations. The idea of revolution in the education system is nonsense. I dislike revolutions as they are very disruptive, costly, unpredictable and cannot be managed. It makes a good show and makes a possibly a few bucks, but it is irresponsible and naive. Education system has been changing, but the task ahead is of such magnitude that it will take time, possibly a few generations to see the outcome. We must not forget that at no time during human history the rate at which scientific and technological discoveries occur has been of such speed and magnitude. To blame the education system when people are still struggling with nationalism, xenophobia, tribal mentality, bigotry and a multitude of other social problems is simply unfair and undermines the good work of many who have dedicated their life to it.

At the core of every „problem” is: what is what we want. That is driven by values. What do WE consider as valuable and what not? Kids have an extreme tendency to exactly follow the values and ideas communicated to them by their parents. As parents you have to be really carful if your own attitude encourages or discourages learning. The U.S., but also many other societies are driven by stereotypes and ideologies:  EVERY German is punctual. EVERY Asian is smart. Most of the them are plain wrong. But media keeps repeating them, as people LOVE hearing ideology that has been taught to them. If give this warm feeling of false confidence.
There are a couple of stereotypes and values typical for the U.S., that harm education in certain social groups.
1.) “You have to work hard to make it”. Mostly wrong. In an industrialized society you have to work smart to make it. The hard work is done by the cheapest people that only have one skill to offer: muscle power. Those are the worst paid jobs. In the US usually done by immigrants.
2.) “Don’t depend on others. A real man makes it on his one.” Mostly wrong. That might have been true for a short period during the colonization, where there was nobody else available. But in todays world cooperation and collaboration are essential factors to success.
3.) “Don’t waist your time learning. You can learn it on the job. Go make money”. No. You can’t. Todays works has gotten so complex and complicated, that without proper training you are not being accepted for higher paid jobs at all. You need to continue to learn while on the job. But without the proper foundation only very few will make it.
4.) “They will anyways not accept you – don’t even try”. If you are black you just can’t make it. Wrong. You can be the US president. But if you never start learning you will never get anywhere
These stereotypes typically infect the minds of lower class and lower middle-class people, who usually have a low education level themselves. And they pass them on to their children. 
It is a measured fact that the success of children in the education system strongly depends on the attitude of their parents to the value of education. E.g. in Finland you have to work smart. You can’t just go out and be a farmer. The weather conditions in Finland are way to harsh. In Finland you can only survive if you use advanced technologies. You MUST learn. The more advanced the better. The same applies to Japan. 80% of Japan are too step for farming. In these countries’ education is one the highest values. IN many parts of the U.S. it is not.
The talk isn’t all wrong. But the key issue is: only when U.S. parents (not the government) VALUE education as really important the situation will change.

title: How Does a Quantum Computer Work?
description:
For more on spin, check out: http://youtu.be/v1_-LsQLwkA
This video was supported by TechNYou: http://bit.ly/19bBX5G
A quantum computer works in a totally different way from a classical computer. Quantum bits or 'qubits' can exist in a superposition state of both zero and one simultaneously. This means that a set of two qubits can be in a superposition of four states, which therefore require four numbers to uniquely identify the state. So the amount of information stored in N qubits is two to the power of N classical bits.

Thank you to Andrea Morello and UNSW. For more info, check out: http://bit.ly/17wZ7lt

If people try to explain how a classical computer works it's no problem: 
you draw a few gates which make up a full adder with carry, and you show 
how the adder adds 1st input bit, 2nd input bit and the carry, and outputs 
an output bit and a carry . 
Then you take 8 full adders, wire them correctly and you've got an 8bit adder which can add
numbers 0 <= x <= 127  coded in a base-2 system. 
Then you can explain how a multiplication works.
People can immediately get an idea how such a computer might work.

title: How the oceans can clean themselves: Boyan Slat at TEDxDelft
description:
18-year-old Boyan Slat combines environmentalism, entrepreneurism and technology to tackle global issues of sustainability. After diving in Greece, and coming across more plastic bags than fish, he wondered; "why can't we clean this up?"

While still being on secondary school, he then decided to dedicate half a year of research to understand plastic pollution and the problems associated with cleaning it up.
This ultimately led to his passive clean-up concept, which he presented at TEDxDelft 2012.
Working to prove the feasibility of his concept, Boyan Slat currently gives lead to a team of approximately 50 people, and temporarily quit his Aerospace Engineering study to completely focus his efforts on The Ocean Cleanup.

The progress of The Ocean Cleanup can be followed through www.theoceancleanup.com, www.facebook.com/TheOceanCleanup, as well as www.twitter.com/TheOceanCleanup.
In the spirit of ideas worth spreading, TEDx is a program of local, self-organized events that bring people together to share a TED-like experience. At a TEDx event, TEDTalks video and live speakers combine to spark deep discussion and connection in a small group. These local, self-organized events are branded TEDx, where x = independently organized TED event. The TED Conference provides general guidance for the TEDx program, but individual TEDx events are self-organized.* (*Subject to certain rules and regulations)

title: How to green the world's deserts and reverse climate change | Allan Savory
description:
"Desertification is a fancy word for land that is turning to desert," begins Allan Savory in this quietly powerful talk. And terrifyingly, it's happening to about two-thirds of the world's grasslands, accelerating climate change and causing traditional grazing societies to descend into social chaos. Savory has devoted his life to stopping it. He now believes -- and his work so far shows -- that a surprising factor can protect grasslands and even reclaim degraded land that was once desert.

TEDTalks is a daily video podcast of the best talks and performances from the TED Conference, where the world's leading thinkers and doers give the talk of their lives in 18 minutes (or less). Look for talks on Technology, Entertainment and Design -- plus science, business, global issues, the arts and much more.

comments.topLevelComment:
During the last ice age, Europe had vast herds of animals who grew to huge proportions on the grasslands stretching across the continent.  Some animals intermixed in their grazing, but most grazed the plains in succession.  Massive herds of gigantic bison ate the bounty of the grasslands at a slightly different time than the different huge deer and elk species and other mammals.  One type of mammal might eat the emerging shoots as they migrated through an area, followed later by another groups of mammals eating more mature grass, followed by others eating tall standing grass, and others preferring the dried grasses, etc.  Mammoths and woolly rhinoceroses liked colder areas closer to the glaciers.  Smaller deer (without the massive antlers of their larger cousins) grazed in the forests.  But all these animals migrated seasonally through the feeding areas, eating the available food at different times, rarely competing for the exact same resource.  As they moved through, they trampled the grasses and left their dung and urine (and sometimes their bones when they fell to four-legged predators or human hunters) to nourish the soil as Allan Savory described.  The grasslands renewed themselves every year until the retreat of the glaciers changed the climate.  

As others have mentioned, America was much like this when we had single bison herds numbering in the millions migrating across the western plains.  But those grasslands were also shared by other large herds of  mammal species also migrating through at different times as well.  Therefore, it seems to me that if we could restore herds of mixed species to some of our desertified lands, we might achieve what Allan Savory has done in his projects.  I hope he is consulting with the American government and park service to do just that!  But we'd also have to restore their natural predators to keep the herds in check (Savory mentioned the lions in the African projects.)

Peter Andrews has been doing this for 35 years in Australia - He calls it Holistic Land Management - Returning it back to how it was before farming led to soil erosion and salt build up. Check out https://youtu.be/-4OBcRHX1Bc
Astonishing....this should not only be the recommended solution...it should be a mandated rule for all regions of the planet...

Back in the nineties in Pakistan I tried to introduce holistic resource management (Alan Savory book) for 3.5 years. Extremely complicated to introduce as it is not only about trampling by moving livestock, it also includes "planning for natural regeneration" and as such avoid overgrazing. In case of common grazing areas, all animals have to join the herd. If few animals do not join but allowed to graze uncontrolled, these few animals WILL overgraze (and kill) the most edible grass species and at the same time grow better then their 'colleagues' in the herd... 
So all farmers with grazing animals have to be convinced for their animals to join the herd. The herd must move according to a certain plan in order to increase natural regeneration. 
So if land is owned and used by one or few farmers (or government), then quite easy to introduce. On common land very difficult.
I thank Alan Savory because I learned a lot from him.

title: How to Have a Good Conversation | Celeste Headlee | TEDxCreativeCoast
description:
When your job hinges on how well you talk to people, you learn a lot about how to have great conversations – and most of us don’t converse very well. A great conversation requires a balance between talking and listening. This balance is important because bad communication leads to bad relationships, at home, at work, everywhere.

Celeste Headlee has worked in public radio since 1999, as a reporter, host, and correspondent. She was the Midwest Correspondent for NPR before becoming the co-host of the PRI show The Takeaway. She also guest hosted a number of NPR shows including Tell Me More, Talk of the Nation, Weekend All Things Considered, and Weekend Edition. 
 
Celeste holds multiple degrees in music and still performs as a professional opera singer. She's the granddaughter of composer William Grant Still, the Dean of African American Composers. Celeste is an avid hiker, biker, paddler and dog walker.

This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at http://ted.com/tedx

Conversational competence is the most overlooked skill. How to talk, how to listen. There's no need to show you are paying attention, if you are already paying attention. 
1. Don't multitask. Be present in that moment. 
2. Don't pontificate. If you want not to have someone disagreed, write a blog. True conversation means setting aside yourself. 
3. Use open ended questions- use who, what, when, where, how...how did that feel...
4. Let the flow come and go
5- say you don't know when you don't
6- don't equate your experience with others. Conversations are not promotion
7- don't keep repeating yourself
8- forget the details- dates etc
9-Listen- if your mouth is open, you are not learning. Nobody listened his way out of the job.
10- be brief. Be interested in other people. Everyone has something amazing.

title: Quantum Entanglement & Spooky Action at a Distance
description:
Does quantum entanglement make faster-than-light communication possible?
What is NOT random? http://bit.ly/NOTrandoVe
First, I know this video is not easy to understand. Thank you for taking the time to attempt to understand it. I've been working on this for over six months over which time my understanding has improved. Quantum entanglement and spooky action at a distance are still debated by professors of quantum physics (I know because I discussed this topic with two of them).

Does hidden information (called hidden variables by physicists) exist? If it does, the experiment violating Bell inequalities indicates that hidden variables must update faster than light - they would be considered 'non-local'. On the other hand if you don't consider the spins before you make the measurement then you could simply say hidden variables don't exist and whenever you measure spins in the same direction you always get opposite results, which makes sense since angular momentum must be conserved in the universe.

Everyone agrees that quantum entanglement does not allow information to be transmitted faster that light. There is no action either detector operator could take to signal the other one - regardless of the choice of measurement direction, the measured spins are random with 50/50 probability of up/down.

Special thanks to:
Prof. Stephen Bartlett, University of Sydney: http://bit.ly/1xSosoJ
Prof. John Preskill, Caltech: http://bit.ly/1y8mJut

Looking Glass Universe: http://bit.ly/17zZH7l
Physics Girl: http://bit.ly/PhysGirl
MinutePhysics: http://bit.ly/MinPhys
Community Channel: http://bit.ly/CommChannel
Nigel, Helen, Luke, and Simon for comments on earlier drafts of this video.

Filmed in part by Scott Lewis: http://google.com/+scottlewis

Music by Amarante "One Last Time": http://bit.ly/VeAmarante

my seemingly natural (trivial?) construction of the hidden information model which gives 50% probability (not 5/9). I wrote up the expected 'experiment result' in this google sheet and found out the probability is as expected, 0.5.
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/175c-L1JAvRfKnVXSrb0mhifMDxY0HlyxNpmnszX6e8k/edit#gid=0

It goes as follows: the hidden information is a direction - the first particle A has a direction between 0-360 degrees, and B has the oppositve direction (+180 degrees). When measured, each particle will follow the cos^2(theta/2) formula to determine the probability of it giving a spin up or spin down as a result.

You can change the 'hidden information' of A to any direction between 0 and 360 (orange cell) and the calculated probability of measuring opposite spins will remain 0.5 (blue cell).

title: 5 ways to listen better | Julian Treasure
description:
http://www.ted.com In our louder and louder world, says sound expert Julian Treasure, "We are losing our listening." In this short, fascinating talk, Treasure shares five ways to re-tune your ears for conscious listening -- to other people and the world around you.

TEDTalks is a daily video podcast of the best talks and performances from the TED Conference, where the world's leading thinkers and doers give the talk of their lives in 18 minutes. Featured speakers have included Al Gore on climate change, Philippe Starck on design, Jill Bolte Taylor on observing her own stroke, Nicholas Negroponte on One Laptop per Child, Jane Goodall on chimpanzees, Bill Gates on malaria and mosquitoes, Pattie Maes on the "Sixth Sense" wearable tech, and "Lost" producer JJ Abrams on the allure of mystery. TED stands for Technology, Entertainment, Design, and TEDTalks cover these topics as well as science, business, development and the arts. Closed captions and translated subtitles in a variety of languages are now available on TED.com, at http://www.ted.com/translate.

I find his arguments for income inequalities in America largely specious. Mr Krugman pontificates as if no one with a lower income is aware of what wealth is or how it's managed.

He has foolishly trotted out that canard about health insurance and how the HCRA benefitted people. Firstly, he demonstrates his own naive understanding of what health care is like in the USA for people of low to moderate income.

 There are 3 basic ways low income people receive health care, and it hasn't changed by any significance since the passage of the HCRA. 
1- Show up as an emergency indigent person in need.
2- Medicare recipient.
3- Health insurance through employment. This is where most people who have insurance obtain it. The worse part is, premiums have escalated significantly as well as deductibles, and co-pays. 
A small fraction of the population, who were unable to afford health insurance, still can't because even the government site is ridiculous. It's like paying COBRA rates. The burden for states, already having financial difficulties, increased substantially when their Medicare coverage costs escalated to cover the totally uninsured who applied for subsidies. So where or in what tangible (not theoretical) way have we benefitted through the passage of the HCRA?

There's this imagined bogeyman called "the wealthy", which as the story goes in Capitalism 101, we're to aspire, but once you have wealth, you're selfish, greedy, and undeserving. How's that work for you?

If that's your target to save the country, you've done a ready fire aim approach. 

If you want to use statistics then what are the wealthy paying in real-time tax dollars after credits, deductions, etc? I'm not talking about the legal entities, corporations, but the people who work and or own major shares. 

Those 10% wealthy, Krugman refers to pay over 70% of the taxes. Furthermore, even during times of higher or more progressive tax rates, the money collected for the treasury has remained around 17.5% effective. 

What isn't being addressed, and continues to be our American challenge is the vast difference we collect in taxes vs. what we as a nation spend.

I've been a working person since I was 15 and never obtained much wealth, but I can still say, I've lived well and I haven't lost any sleep over what the wealthy receive in compensation or gave accumulated. If Mr. Krugman is feeling burdened or guilty from his aggregate economic benefits, I will gladly swap saving, investments, and bank accounts with him.

The America I live in, for almost 7 decades, is a far more kind and generous country than what Mr. Krugman claims. His description of "an ugly America" is far from what I've seen. And yes, I've seen most of it. These alarmist claims, based on incorrect assumptions and data defy what people who have worked most of their lives to achieve. Unlike the summary given by Bill Moyers, I don't envy nor am I jealous of the Bezos, Buffets, Gates, Soros, Koch brothers, or the Walton family. Should they be forced by law to pay those who work for them more money, or pay higher taxes? I guess that's still open for debate, but in so far as I have learned, if you personally produce or possess something of great value, then you're very likely to be compensated according to that value.
The 1% works hard instead of bitching about it on youtube. Inheritence is a totally different issue I agree.
11:25. Funny how people who accumulate some wealth and think they are part of the wealthy class. Yet, they could be wiped out in any major economic crash. They have no idea what real wealth is.

title: I've lived as a man & a woman -- here's what I learned | Paula Stone Williams | TEDxMileHigh
description: If you’re a man, at one point or another you’ve probably thought to yourself, “I will never understand women!” And if you’re a woman, “what's wrong with men?!” But your gender is all you've ever known, so how could you understand? As a transgender woman, Paula Stone Williams has lived on both sides, “and the differences are massive!” In this funny and insightful talk, Paula shares her wisdom for all. Reverend Dr. Paula Stone Williams is the president of RLT Pathways, Inc., a non-profit providing counseling and coaching services. She works with the Center for Progressive Renewal, serves on the board of the Gay Christian Network, and is an active member at Highlands Church in Denver. She has been featured in the New York Times, The Denver Post, and Colorado Public Radio, and is a blogger for The Huffington Post. She is an avid runner and mountain biker with three children and five granddaughters. This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at https://www.ted.com/tedx

title: Transcendental Meditation Technique - A Complete Introduction
description:
http://tm.org In this introductory video, Bob Roth describes the Transcendental Meditation® technique in depth. What you'll learn:

• What TM is
• What TM is not
• What happens during TM
• How we know TM really works
• TM's effect on the brain
• The natural tendency of the mind
• What a mantra is
• Where TM came from
• How TM is different
• Why TM works for everyone

To learn more about the TM® technique, visit http://www.TM.org or call 1-888-LEARN-TM (1-888-532-7686)

comments.topLevelComment: This is very interesting, I will save up to take this course. Thank you
I can’t wait to try TM, I have saved enough money it took me long time. I have meditated for the last 10 years on and off and it has helped me a lot with my anxiety.

TM has changed my life 🌻 I’ve struggled with clinical depression and GAD my entire adult life and this is the only thing that has ever given me peace. I had tried so many things to help with this (drugs, other types of meditation, alcohol, yoga) nothing has impacted me as profoundly as TM. After my first time practicing the technique I felt like I had become a new person. It’s worth every penny. I’m current 24 years old and am so happy I found TM. Your thoughts are not your enemy. You don’t always have to numb yourself to escape. We just need to heal and TM is the only thing I’ve come across that helps you heal from within. If you’re watching this video wondering if you should try this, I highly encourage you attend an intro class close to you and get educated on how this practice can help you. Pure consciousness>

I practice TM, 20 minutes, twice a day, and it's incredibly helpful for me. I feel calm, focused, and happy. Also I have much more energy and I'm not prone to anger. I look forward to it each day. It's like a calming bath for the mind. Definitely, read this man's book about it. I couldn't put it down. The cost of learning TM is worth every penny and there's aid for those in need. Once you learn it you have lifetime support from the most wonderful people at TM Centers including retreats, further education, social events, and more. Just a sincere comment from a passionate computer student living in the U.S.A.

title: How I overcame alcoholism | Claudia Christian | TEDxLondonBusinessSchool
description:
A hugely successful actress who saw her personal life and career tested by addiction, Claudia shares her journey of overcoming alcoholism and offers fresh perspectives on alcohol use disorder treatments.

Claudia Christian landed her first TV series at 18 on NBC’s nighttime drama Berringers and her first studio feature at 20 in New Line Cinema’s cult hit “The Hidden.” Over 50 films, hundreds of TV shows and 5 music albums later, Claudia has worked with George Clooney, Kirk Douglas, Faye Dunaway, Nicolas Cage and countless other luminaries. 

This talk was given at a TEDx event using the TED conference format but independently organized by a local community. Learn more at http://ted.com/tedx

as bigknowno has mentioned below having a bad experience, be cautious when first introduced to Naltrexone. If you have severe acute anxiety, this medication will or may set your anxiety off big time. I am sure the medication has helped many people, but try a half dose pill first to see if you have any adverse reactions to it. Definitely do not try the shot first. If you are addicted to benzodiazepines use caution when you first try this medication. If you have bad reactions to anti-depressants such as zoloft, Lexapro , SSRI's etc...Use caution when first trying Naltrexone, it is in many ways an anti-depressant.
comments.reply: TSM recommends using a half dose for a few weeks. The side effects are typically minimal and go away after a week or so. But I agree, learn all you can about the method - and take it slow at first.

comments.topLevelComment: My wife was a severe alcoholic for the first 20 years of our 40 year marriage. It was very tough time and nothing helped. Then in 1994 her mother who had been living with us with Alzheimer's DZ passed away. My wife quit cold and stopped smoking as well. I could never get her to tell me what it was that stopped her self destructive habits. She took it to the grave with her. But it was precisely timed with her mother's death.

After years of trying to to stop drinking though AA, cold turkey, treatment, and local doctors and addiction counselor. I traveled 300 miles and went to an addiction specialist. They ordered genetic testing for me and found that I had an MTHFR genetic anomaly. I too was put on Naltrexone using the Sinclair method. This along with 4 supplements and a diet change to treat other ongoing issues from the genetic anomaly. 7 months on and I have not drank in 5 months, and with treatment for the depreasion, anxiety, and sleep disorder that were a product of the MTHFR anomoly I feel even better at 42 than I did in high school. It was a lifesaver for me. I was so excited I shared my success with two online AA groups that I participated in. To my surprise I was scorned by the group's admins for promoting things outside of the "Big Book" and was booted from one of the groups. Thanks for sharing this. I hope anyone struggling gives it a try.
I've been sober over 25 years. It was AA and a guy named Leo that helped get me where I am now.

the  Sinclair  method  uses  a  drug ..that  is  not  recovery
comments.reply: You only use the med to get you to 100% abstinence (and without any cravings or thoughts of alcohol). Once you are there (in 4-12 months), you are done using naltrexone. Traditional thinking is you need to quit cold-turkey and live with cravings one-day-at-a-time and go to meetings for the rest of your life. Many people relapse with these traditional methods. Relapse is rare with TSM - which is proven very effective in over 70 clinical studies.

This is an interesting story, and I'm all for whatever helps someone cease to be a pathetic addict. I myself had become a chronic drinker largely due to living on one of the Top 5 Most Alcoholic Cities in America, though bordedom, loneliness and/or frustration were exacerbating factors. Basically: going along to get along. I eventually quit, with no AA, no counseling, no chemical treatment – just comprehensive disgust with alcohol, its effect upon my life, and its prevalence in the world around me. For the first few months (after getting down to regular-but-moderate amounts), I fell into a deep depression, which apparently occurs because the brain grows accustomed to alcohol's presence for the endophin action. After riding that out, I felt great, getting re-acquainted with my true self, and have no compulsion ever to drink acohol.
